summary: This document contains due diligence research results for Erika Kellerhals, including various searches for negative and non-negative media, public records, and personal information. It details her addresses, phone numbers, and associations, as well as her professional licenses and corporate affiliations. The document is marked confidential and is intended for internal use only. This document discusses a bankruptcy appeal filed by North Shore Real Estate Corporation, which was dismissed due to failure to prosecute. The court evaluated the case based on the Poulis factors, which assess the appellant's responsibility and the impact of their actions on the proceedings. Ultimately, the court granted the motion to dismiss the appeal. This document discusses the Poulis factors in relation to North Shore's appeal in a bankruptcy case. It assesses North Shore's responsibility for failing to comply with court orders, the prejudice caused to the appellee, and the history of dilatoriness in the case. The court ultimately finds that dismissal of North Shore's appeal is warranted due to its repeated failures to meet deadlines and the lack of a meritorious claim. This document discusses the legal standards and procedures related to fraudulent transfers and the recovery of post-petition transfers in bankruptcy cases. It specifically addresses the claims made by Carroll against North Shore, detailing the court's findings regarding the sufficiency of evidence and the denial of North Shore's motion for reconsideration. The court ultimately grants Carroll's motion to dismiss North Shore's appeal for failure to prosecute. This document details the proceedings of a divorce case between Julito A. Francis and Dr. Debra Wright-Francis, including the division of property and financial disputes. The court addressed various motions and stipulations regarding the marital homestead and financial obligations, with testimony from both parties and their legal representatives. This document discusses the equitable distribution of marital assets in the divorce proceedings between Dr. Wright-Francis and Mr. Francis. It outlines the court's findings regarding the division of property, including retirement accounts and the marital homestead, and addresses the claims made by both parties regarding their contributions and entitlements. This document discusses a court ruling regarding the financial disputes between Dr. Wright-Francis and Mr. Francis following their divorce. The court found insufficient evidence to support claims that Mr. Francis excessively spent marital assets, concluding that both parties had adequate resources to maintain their standard of living post-divorce.

events.title: Notice of Appeal Filed
events.description: North Shore Real Estate Corporation filed a notice of appeal from the judgment of the Bankruptcy Court.

events.title: Court Order Issued
events.description: The court issued an order requiring North Shore to file a designation of record and statement of issues.

events.title: Motion for Leave Filed
events.description: North Shore filed a motion for leave to file an untimely designation of record and statement of issues.

events.title: Second Court Order Issued
events.description: The court issued a second order requiring North Shore to file a designation of record and statement of issues.

events.title: Deadline for Filing
events.description: The court set a deadline for North Shore to file necessary documents, failing which the appeal may be dismissed.

events.title: Bankruptcy Court Judgment
events.description: The Bankruptcy Court issued a judgment against North Shore, which included a summary judgment in favor of Carroll.

events.title: Scheduling Order
events.description: The court issued a scheduling order that North Shore failed to comply with, leading to discussions of dismissal.

events.title: Bankruptcy Court Decision
events.description: The bankruptcy court ruled in favor of Carroll, granting a motion to dismiss North Shore's appeal for failure to prosecute.

events.title: Affidavit Submission
events.description: Dawn Prosser's affidavit was submitted and referenced in the court's decision regarding North Shore's motion for reconsideration.

events.title: Petition for Divorce Filed
events.description: Julito Francis filed a verified Petition for Divorce against Dr. Wright-Francis.

events.title: Divorce Decree Issued
events.description: The Court issued a Divorce Decree to Julito A. Francis and Dr. Wright-Francis, dissolving their marriage.

events.title: Final Hearing
events.description: The Court held a final hearing to resolve outstanding issues regarding the distribution of personal property.

events.title: Trial Commencement
events.description: The trial commenced to determine the parties' personal property and marital homestead.

events.title: Court Hearing on Asset Distribution
events.description: The court refused to make a determination on Dr. Wright-Francis's motion due to insufficient evidence and ordered the parties to commission a CPA.

events.title: Purchase of Condominium
events.description: Dr. Wright-Francis confirmed the purchase of a unit at the Towers Condominiums, which she currently rents out.

events.title: Court Order Issued
events.description: A court order was issued regarding the financial obligations and asset management between Dr. Wright-Francis and Mr. Francis.

keyFacts: The document is a due diligence report on Erika Kellerhals, indicating no significant negative media results.
Erika Kellerhals has multiple addresses listed, primarily in Staten Island, NY, and St. Thomas, VI.
The report includes personal information such as date of birth, SSN, and phone numbers for Erika Kellerhals.
Several associates and relatives of Erika Kellerhals are mentioned, including Edward and Kathleen Kellerhals.
The document is marked confidential and is intended for internal use only.
North Shore Real Estate Corporation failed to file a designation of record and statement of issues as required by the court.
James P. Carroll filed a motion to dismiss the appeal due to North Shore's lack of prosecution.
The court evaluated the case based on the six Poulis factors before deciding to dismiss the appeal.
The court found that North Shore's failure to comply with court orders warranted dismissal of the appeal.
The document outlines the procedural history and the legal standards applicable to bankruptcy appeals.
North Shore failed to comply with the court's original scheduling order and did not file its brief within the required time frame.
Dawn Prosser's affidavit was deemed insufficient in addressing Carroll's requests for admission, leading to those requests being deemed admitted.
The court found that North Shore's conduct has prejudiced Carroll by hampering his ability to resolve the underlying bankruptcy matter.
The court found that North Shore failed to meet its burden of proof in the bankruptcy case.
Dawn Prosser's affidavit contained only general denials, which were insufficient to support North Shore's claims.
The bankruptcy court's denial of North Shore's motion for reconsideration was upheld due to lack of new evidence.
The court emphasized that a motion for reconsideration cannot be used to relitigate old matters or present evidence that could have been raised earlier.
The court granted Carroll's motion to dismiss North Shore's appeal for failure to prosecute.
Julito A. Francis and Dr. Debra Wright-Francis were married on August 17, 1991.
The parties have two daughters: Saryn J. Francis and Brooklyn J. Francis.
A Divorce Decree was entered on July 25, 2012, dissolving the marriage.
Julito A. Francis claims that Dr. Wright-Francis' medical license is marital property.
The marital homestead is valued at $725,000, subject to a mortgage of $110,000.
Dr. Wright-Francis is entitled to half of the wasted amount from Mr. Francis's early withdrawal from his annuity.
The court determined that the marital homestead is valued at $725,000, subject to a $110,000 mortgage.
Dr. Wright-Francis's medical degree is considered her separate property and not subject to equitable distribution.
The parties have approximately equal amounts in their retirement accounts, leading to a decision that no division is necessary.
The court found that Mr. Francis should retain possession of the marital homestead based on the contributions and circumstances surrounding its acquisition.
Dr. Wright-Francis claims Mr. Francis excessively spent marital assets, but the court found no evidence of intent to harm marital property.
Mr. Francis withdrew $220,179.93 from his annuity between 2011 and 2012 for necessary expenses.
The court concluded that both parties have sufficient resources to support themselves and their children post-divorce.
